examples.explanation: A screen reader would just say 'Button' without the label. With aria-label, it says 'Close Button'.

common_mistakes.correction: First rule of ARIA: Don't use ARIA. Use standard HTML elements whenever possible.
Images need alt text. ARIA doesn't replace basic HTML requirements.

interview_questions.question: What is the first rule of ARIA?
interview_questions.answer: The first rule of ARIA is: If you can use a native HTML element (like <button> or <input>) instead of a custom element with ARIA, do so.

interview_questions.question: What is aria-label used for?
interview_questions.answer: It provides a text label for screen readers when an element doesn't have visible text (like an icon-only button).

practice_problems.problem: Make a decorative <div> containing an icon invisible to screen readers.

real_world_use_cases.description: When building a custom React/Vue dropdown, you MUST use aria-expanded and aria-haspopup to tell blind users that a menu has appeared.

summary: Accessibility is a right, not a feature. While semantic HTML gets you 90% of the way there, ARIA attributes help bridge the gap for complex, dynamic interfaces, ensuring everyone can use your website.
